sen.j: 用語としては『日本書紀』巻第29、天武天皇14年11月24日（丙寅）条に「是日為天皇招魂之」とあるが、『釈日本紀』巻21秘訓6 はこの「招魂」を「ミタマフリス」と訓じ、同書巻15、述義11では「今鎮魂祭也」として、『日本書紀』の「招魂」の記述を「鎮魂祭」のこことしている。
sen.e: The term Shokon no matsuri ni first used in "Chronicles of Japan", Volume 29, under "Emperor Tenmu" in article "Fake Shokon no matsuri of the Emperor". In "Shaku Nihogi", volumme 21, verse 6, this "Shokon no matsuri" is referred to as "matafuris", and in volume 15 of the same book, in article 11, it is called "Chinkon no matsuri"

The term Shokon no matsuri was used in "Chronicles of Japan," Volume 29, an article on November 24 (day of Hinoe Tora) of the 14th year of Emperor Tenmu that states, 'Shokon was performed for the Emperor on that day.'

sen.j: 伴信友はまた「比古婆衣」第20巻で「後醍醐天皇日中行事に、日毎せうこんの御祭、今は定まれる事なり、とあるせうこんは招魂にて、こは鎮魂にはあらず、陰陽家にて別に招魂祭とて為る方なるべし」 と述べて、招魂祭と鎮魂祭との区別を明確にしている。
sen.e: In Hikobae (Essays on Study of Historical Artefacts of Nobutomo BAN), volume 20, he writes, "During Emperor Godaigo's rule, a ritual was performed daily; if it were done today, there would be severe punishment. This ritual was not a chinkon no matsuri, but a shokon no matsuri," and makes a clear distinction betwen the two types of rituals.

In Hikobae (Essays on Study of Historical Artefacts of Nobutomo BAN), volume 20, he writes, "Emperor GoDaigo's 'Nicchu Gyoji' (book on the ceremonies of the court) states "the daily rituals of shokon have been established " where shokon refers to a shokon no matsuri performed by a onmyo-ji, not a chinkon no matsuri," making a clear distinction between the two types of rituals.
